sen.j: 荘園領主（しょうえんりょうしゅ）とは、荘園を支配する領主のこと。
sen.e: Shoen-ryoshu is the lord that governed Shoen (manor.)
Shoen-ryoshu was a lord that governed a Shoen (manor).
"Shoen-ryoshu" was a lord that governed a Shoen (manor).
sen.cmt: 統一リスト（その他 2009/6/29）の指示により、Shoen-ryoshu にダブルクォーテーションを追記しました。

sen.j: 一般的には荘園支配の上層部に立つ本家・領家などを指す。
sen.e: Generally, the word Shoen-ryoshu indicates "honke" and "ryoke," the highest class that governed Shoen.
The word Shoen-ryoshu was a commonly used term to indicate "honke" and "ryoke," the highest classes that governed Shoen.
sen.cmt: Generally→was a commonly used term; fixed grammar
sen.e: The word Shoen-ryoshu was a commonly used term to indicate the honke (patron) and the ryoke (proprietor), the highest classes that governed Shoen.
sen.cmt: "honke" and "ryoke," ダブルクォーテーションを削除し、それぞれに定冠詞 the および意味 (patron), (proprietor) を追記しました。

sen.j: ただし、これは歴史学において荘園現地の大土地所有者である「在地領主」との対比として用いられている用語であり、当時において実際に用いられていた用語ではない。
sen.e: But the term Shoen-ryoshu is used in the historical science in contrast to "zaichi-ryoshu (resident landholder)" who owned and lived in the vast property land and the word was not actually used in those days.

Although the term Shoen-ryoshu is used in historical science in contrast to the term "zaichi-ryoshu" (resident landholder) who were owners of vast properties of land, this term was not actually used during that time period.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more easily
sen.e: Although the term Shoen-ryoshu is used in historical science in contrast to the term 'zaichi-ryoshu' (resident landholder) who were owners of vast properties of land, this term was not actually used during that time period.
sen.cmt: "zaichi-ryoshu" をシングルクォーテーションに修正しました。

sen.j: 日本中世の荘園における荘園領主とは、いわゆる「権門勢家」のことを指し、貴族や寺社が想定される場合が多いが、武門の棟梁であった鎌倉殿も関東御領などの広大な荘園を有した荘園領主であった。
sen.e: Shoen-ryoshu in the medieval period in Japan indicates so-called "kenmon-seike (the great and powerful families)"and it often reminds us of the nobles and temples and shrines, but Kamakura-dono (lord of Kamakura), the head of the samurai warrior families, was also a Shoen-ryoshu that owned vast manors.

Although Shoen-ryoshu of the medieval period in Japan indicates the so-called "kenmon-seike" (the great and powerful families) and is often inferential to nobles, temples and shrines, Kamakura-dono (the lord of Kamkura), as the head of samurai warrior families, was also a Shoen-ryoshu who owned vast manors.
sen.cmt: changed 1st person to 3rd person; fixed grammar
sen.e: Although Shoen-ryoshu of the medieval period in Japan indicates the so-called 'kenmon-seike' (the great and powerful families) and is often inferential to nobles, temples and shrines, Kamakura-dono (the lord of Kamkura), as the head of samurai warrior families, was also a Shoen-ryoshu who owned vast manors.
sen.cmt: "kenmon-seike"をシングルクォーテーションに修正しました。

sen.j: 11世紀に寄進地系荘園及び職の体系が確立されると、公家領においては天皇家や摂関家などの上級貴族層が在地領主などからの寄進を受けて本家職や領家職などを集中させ、家司・政所などの家政組織を運営して、現地から年貢・公事などを徴収していった。
sen.e: With the establishment of the system of "kishinchikei-shoen (donated manors)" and "shiki (the rigts of Shoen clerks to Shoen)," in kuge-ryo (Court nobles' territory), the high-ranked nobles of Imperial family and Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents) were donated land from zaichi-ryoshu and gained the rights of "honke-shiki" and "ryoke-shi" and collected "nengu and kuji (land and other taxes)" from the land by setting and making use of its domestic governing system such as Keishi (household superintendent) and Mandokoro (an office set up the houses of powerful aristocrats in the Heian Period for the administration of their vast property estates.)

In the 11th century, as "kishinchikei-shoen" (donated manors) and "shiki" (the right of Shoen clerks in a Shoen) were established within kuge-ryo (territory owned by court nobles), the high-ranked nobles of the Imperial Family and Sekken-ke (families that produced regents) received land donated by zaichi-ryoshu (resident landholders) and they gained the rights of "honke-shiki" (head family) and "ryoke-shi"(lord of a manor) and collected "nengu" and "shiki" (land and other taxes) from the land by setting and making use of a domestic governing system such as Keishi (household superindendent) and Mandokoro (an office set up in the houses of powerful aristocrats in the Heian Period for the administration of their vast property estates).
sen.cmt: added the terms for "honke-shiki" (head family) and "ryoke-shi" (lord of a manor; fixed grammar mistakes
sen.e: As kishinchikei-shoen (donated manors) and shiki (the right of Shoen clerks in a Shoen) were established in the 11th century, within kuge-ryo (territory owned by court nobles), the high-ranked nobles of the Imperial Family and Sekkan-ke (the line of regents and advisers) received land donated by zaichi-ryoshu (resident landholders), concentrated their honke-shiki and ryoke-shiki (economical right as patron and proprietor), and collected nengu and kuji (land tax and public duties) from the land by setting and making use of a domestic governing system such as Keishi (household superindendent) and Mandokoro (an office set up in the houses of powerful aristocrats in the Heian Period for the administration of their vast property estates).
sen.cmt: ダブルクォーテーションを全て削除しました。「11世紀に寄進地系荘園及び職の体系が確立されると、公家領においては」の語順を入れ替えました（※）。※ trans2 の訳では「11世紀に寄進地系荘園及び職が、公家領内で確立されると」という誤訳になるかと思われます。用語集の表記に従い、Sekken-ke (families that produced regents) をSekkan-ke (the line of regents and advisers) に修正しました。「本家職や領家職などを集中させ」gained the rights of honke-shiki (head family) and ryoke-shi(lord of a manor) をconcentrated their honke-shiki and ryoke-shiki (economical right as patron and proprietor) に修正しました。 「年貢・公事などを徴収していった」用語集の表記に従い、collected nengu and shiki (land and other taxes) をcollected nengu and kuji (land tax and public duties) に修正しました。

sen.j: ただし、その権限は自らの政治力に依存するところが大きく、中世に入り公家政権の政治力が低下し、領家職に武家が進出するようになると、直務支配が貫徹された一部を除いては次第に「不知行」化していく。
sen.e: However, their authority to collect taxes depended largely on their own political power, so as the governing power of the Kuge (court nobles) Government decreased and samurai (warrior) families made advances into ryoke-shiki, the power weakened and the nobles were unable to control their land that would become the state of fuchigyo (losing the property land) except some cases of being able to maintain the rights completely.

However, their authority to collect taxes depended largely on their own political power, so when the power of the Kuge (court noble) Government decreased and samurai families made advances into ryoke-shiki, their influence weakened and with the exception of a few cases of maintaining all of their rights, the nobles were unable to control their land and stop it from falling into fuchigyo (losing land property).
sen.cmt: eliminated "governing" to avoid redundancy with the followed "Government"; changed sentence structure to read more easily as one sentence
sen.e: However, their authority to collect taxes depended largely on their own political power, so when the power of the Kuge (court noble) Government decreased and samurai families made advances into ryoke-shiki (proprietorships), their influence weakened and with the exception of a few cases of maintaining all of their rights, the nobles were unable to control their land and stop it from falling into fuchigyo (losing land property).
sen.cmt: 用語集の表記に従い、ryoke-shiki の意味 (proprietorships) を追記しました。

sen.j: 一方、寺社においては比較的早い時期より直務支配を行うための荘務組織が確立されており、本家・領家である寺社の支配が直接的に在地に及ぶ体制が取られていた。
sen.e: On the other hand, in the case of temples and shrines the organization for Shomu (management and control of encouragement of agriculture, taxes and so on in Shoen) to directly control Shoen was established from the relatively early period so that temples and shrine could directly manage their local property land.

In the case of temples and shrines, on the other hand, the Organization of Shomu (management and control of agriculture, taxes, etc in Shoen) had been established at a relatively early period, and a system made it possible for honke-shiki and ryoke-shi of temples and shrines to directly manage their property.
sen.cmt: added "honke-shiki" and "ryoke-shi" to be more consistent with the Japanese; capitalized "Organization of Shomu"; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: In the case of temples and shrines, on the other hand, the Organization of Shomu (management and control of agriculture, taxes, etc in Shoen) had been established at a relatively early period, and a system was taken that allowed temples and shrines of honke or ryoke to manage their property directly.
sen.cmt: 「本家・領家である寺社の支配が直接的に在地に及ぶ体制が取られていた」and a system made it possible for honke-shiki and ryoke-shi of temples and shrines to directly manage their property をand a system was taken that allowed temples and shrines of honke or ryoke to manage their property directly. に修正しました。

sen.j: このため、大寺社の寺社領であった荘園の中には中世後期においても存続していた事例は多い。
sen.e: Therefore, there were many cases that some of the Shoen, which were the property of temples and shrines, were able to continue to exist even into the latter half of the medieval period.
As a result, there were many cases of Shoen that were the property of temples and shrines which were able to endure even into the latter half of the medieval period.
As a result, there were many cases of Shoen that were the property of big temples and shrines which were able to endure even into the latter half of the medieval period.
sen.cmt: 「大寺社の寺社領であった荘園」 「大」が訳漏れのため、 Shoen that were the property of temples and shrines を Shoen that were the property of big temples and shrines に修正しました。

sen.j: なお、南北朝時代 (日本)以後になると前述の武家による侵奪の他に、本家・領家よりも下位の職であった地頭職に貴族や寺社が反対に進出する例も存在しており、そうした意味においても荘園領主という概念が崩壊しつつあったことを示している。
sen.e: Meanwhile, in the period of Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), besides the encroachment into the rights of Shoen by the samurai (warrior) families mentioned above, there were some cases that existed that the nobles and temples and shrines conversely made inroads to Jito-shiki (stewardship rights to manager and lord of a manor), which was lower position rights than Honke and Ryoke, and in this sense as well it indicates that the concept of Shoen-ryoshu was collapsing.

Meanwhile, after the period of Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), along with the encroachment of the samurai into the rights of Shoen, there were a number of cases of nobles, temples and shrines conversely making inroads toward becoming Jito-shiki (stewardship rights to a manager and lord of a manor) which had less rights and was lower in position than Honke and Ryoke, and an indication that the concept of Shoen-ryoshu was collapsing in this sense as well.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to make the sentence read more naturally
sen.e: Meanwhile, after the period of Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), along with the encroachment of the samurai into the rights of Shoen, there were a number of cases of nobles, temples and shrines conversely making inroads toward becoming jito-shiki (stewardship rights) which was lower in position than honke and ryoke, thus, in this case as well, it indicates that the concept of Shoen-ryoshu was collapsing.
sen.cmt: 「本家・領家よりも下位の職であった地頭職」Jito-shiki (stewardship rights to a manager and lord of a manor) which had less rights and was lower in position than Honke and Ryoke をjito-shiki (stewardship rights) which was lower in position than honke and ryoke に修正しました。「そうした意味においても荘園領主という概念が崩壊しつつあったことを示している」and an indication that the concept of Shoen-ryoshu was collapsing in this sense as well をthus, in this case as well, it indicates that the concept of Shoen-ryoshu was collapsing に修正しました。
